segment.source: Theme resources in XAML are a set of resources that apply different values depending on which system theme is active.
segment.target: Theme resources in XAML are a set of resources that apply different values depending on which system theme is active.

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Theme resources in XAML are a set of resources that apply different values depending on which system theme is active.
segment.target: Theme resources in XAML are a set of resources that apply different values depending on which system theme is active.

segment.source: There are 3 themes that the XAML framework supports: "Light", "Dark", and "HighContrast".
segment.target: There are 3 themes that the XAML framework supports: "Light", "Dark", and "HighContrast".

segment.source: This topic assumes that you have read ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references.
segment.target: This topic assumes that you have read ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references.

segment.source: How theme resources differ from static resources
segment.target: How theme resources differ from static resources

segment.source: There are two XAML markup extensions that can reference a XAML resource from an existing XAML resource dictionary: {StaticResource} markup extension and {ThemeResource} markup extension.
segment.target: There are two XAML markup extensions that can reference a XAML resource from an existing XAML resource dictionary: {StaticResource} markup extension and {ThemeResource} markup extension.

segment.source: Evaluation of a {ThemeResource} markup extension occurs when the app loads and subsequently each time the theme changes at runtime.
segment.target: Evaluation of a {ThemeResource} markup extension occurs when the app loads and subsequently each time the theme changes at runtime.

segment.source: This is typically the result of the user changing their device settings or from a programmatic change within the app that alters its current theme.
segment.target: This is typically the result of the user changing their device settings or from a programmatic change within the app that alters its current theme.

segment.source: In contrast, a {StaticResource} markup extension is evaluated only when the XAML is first loaded by the app.
segment.target: In contrast, a {StaticResource} markup extension is evaluated only when the XAML is first loaded by the app.

segment.source: It’s similar to a find and replace in your XAML with the actual runtime value at app launch.
segment.target: It’s similar to a find and replace in your XAML with the actual runtime value at app launch.

segment.source: Theme resources and where they fit in the resource dictionary structure
segment.target: Theme resources and where they fit in the resource dictionary structure

segment.source: Each theme resource is part of the XAML file themeresources.xaml.
segment.target: Each theme resource is part of the XAML file themeresources.xaml.

segment.source: For design purposes, themeresources.xaml is available in the \\(Program Files)\\Windows Kits\\10\\DesignTime\\CommonConfiguration\\Neutral\\UAP\\SDK version\\Generic folder from a Windows Software Development Kit (SDK) installation.
segment.target: For design purposes, themeresources.xaml is available in the \\(Program Files)\\Windows Kits\\10\\DesignTime\\CommonConfiguration\\Neutral\\UAP\\SDK version\\Generic folder from a Windows Software Development Kit (SDK) installation.

segment.source: The resource dictionaries in themeresources.xaml are also reproduced in generic.xaml in the same directory.
segment.target: The resource dictionaries in themeresources.xaml are also reproduced in generic.xaml in the same directory.

segment.source: NoteThe Windows Runtime doesn't use these physical files for runtime lookup.
segment.target: NoteThe Windows Runtime doesn't use these physical files for runtime lookup.

segment.source: That's why they are specifically in a DesignTime folder, and they aren't copied into apps by default.
segment.target: That's why they are specifically in a DesignTime folder, and they aren't copied into apps by default.

segment.source: Instead, these resource dictionaries exist in memory as part of the Windows Runtime itself, and your app's XAML resource references to theme resources (or system resources) resolve there at runtime.
segment.target: Instead, these resource dictionaries exist in memory as part of the Windows Runtime itself, and your app's XAML resource references to theme resources (or system resources) resolve there at runtime.

segment.source: Follow these guidelines when you define and consume your own custom theme resources.
segment.target: Follow these guidelines when you define and consume your own custom theme resources.

segment.source: Specify theme dictionaries for both "Light" and "Dark" in addition to your "HighContrast" dictionary.
segment.target: Specify theme dictionaries for both "Light" and "Dark" in addition to your "HighContrast" dictionary.

segment.source: Although you can create a ResourceDictionary with "Default" as the key, it’s preferred to be explicit and instead use "Light", "Dark", and "HighContrast".
segment.target: Although you can create a ResourceDictionary with "Default" as the key, it’s preferred to be explicit and instead use "Light", "Dark", and "HighContrast".

segment.source: Use the {ThemeResource} markup extension in: Styles, Setters, Control templates, Property setters, and Animations.
segment.target: Use the {ThemeResource} markup extension in: Styles, Setters, Control templates, Property setters, and Animations.

segment.source: Use the {ThemeResource} markup extension in your resource definitions inside your ThemeDictionaries.
segment.target: Use the {ThemeResource} markup extension in your resource definitions inside your ThemeDictionaries.

segment.source: EXCEPTION: it is alright to use the {ThemeResource} markup extension to reference resources that are agnostic to the app theme in your ThemeDictionaries.
segment.target: EXCEPTION: it is alright to use the {ThemeResource} markup extension to reference resources that are agnostic to the app theme in your ThemeDictionaries.

segment.source: Examples of these resources are accent color resources like , or system color resources, which are typically prefixed with "SystemColor" like .
segment.target: Examples of these resources are accent color resources like , or system color resources, which are typically prefixed with "SystemColor" like .

segment.source: Caution If you don’t follow these guidelines, you might see unexpected behavior related to themes in your app.
segment.target: Caution If you don’t follow these guidelines, you might see unexpected behavior related to themes in your app.

segment.source: For more info, see the Troubleshooting theme resources section.
segment.target: For more info, see the Troubleshooting theme resources section.

segment.source: The XAML color ramp and theme-dependent brushes
segment.target: The XAML color ramp and theme-dependent brushes

segment.source: The combined set of colors for "Light", "Dark", and "HighContrast" themes make up the Windows color ramp in XAML.
segment.target: The combined set of colors for "Light", "Dark", and "HighContrast" themes make up the Windows color ramp in XAML.

segment.source: Whether you want to modify the system themes, or apply a system theme to your own XAML elements, it’s important to understand how the color resources are structured.
segment.target: Whether you want to modify the system themes, or apply a system theme to your own XAML elements, it’s important to understand how the color resources are structured.

segment.source: The XAML framework provides a set of named Color resources with values that are tailored for the "Light" and "Dark" themes.
segment.target: The XAML framework provides a set of named Color resources with values that are tailored for the "Light" and "Dark" themes.

segment.source: The keys you use to reference these follow the naming format: .
segment.target: The keys you use to reference these follow the naming format: .

segment.source: This table lists the key, simple name, and string representation of the color (using the \#aarrggbb format) for the "Light" and "Dark" resources provided by the XAML framework.
segment.target: This table lists the key, simple name, and string representation of the color (using the \#aarrggbb format) for the "Light" and "Dark" resources provided by the XAML framework.

segment.source: The key is used to reference the resource in an app.
segment.target: The key is used to reference the resource in an app.

segment.source: The "Simple light/dark name" is used as part of the brush naming convention that we explain later.
segment.target: The "Simple light/dark name" is used as part of the brush naming convention that we explain later.

segment.source: In addition to the set of resources provided by the XAML framework, there's a set of color values derived from the Windows system palette.
segment.target: In addition to the set of resources provided by the XAML framework, there's a set of color values derived from the Windows system palette.

segment.source: These colors are not specific to the Windows Runtime or Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: These colors are not specific to the Windows Runtime or Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: However, many of the XAML Brush resources consume these colors when the system is operating (and the app is running) using the "HighContrast" theme.
segment.target: However, many of the XAML Brush resources consume these colors when the system is operating (and the app is running) using the "HighContrast" theme.

segment.source: The XAML framework provides these system-wide colors as keyed resources.
segment.target: The XAML framework provides these system-wide colors as keyed resources.

segment.source: The keys follow the naming format: .
segment.target: The keys follow the naming format: .

segment.source: This table lists the system-wide colors that XAML provides as resource objects derived from the Windows system palette.
segment.target: This table lists the system-wide colors that XAML provides as resource objects derived from the Windows system palette.

segment.source: The "Ease of Access name" column shows how color is labeled in the Windows settings UI.
segment.target: The "Ease of Access name" column shows how color is labeled in the Windows settings UI.

segment.source: The "Simple HighContrast name" column is a one word description of how the color is applied across the XAML common controls.
segment.target: The "Simple HighContrast name" column is a one word description of how the color is applied across the XAML common controls.

segment.source: It's used as part of the brush naming convention that we explain later.
segment.target: It's used as part of the brush naming convention that we explain later.

segment.source: The "Initial default" column shows the values you'd get if the system is not running in high contrast at all.
segment.target: The "Initial default" column shows the values you'd get if the system is not running in high contrast at all.

segment.source: Windows provides different high-contrast themes, and enables the user to set the specific colors to for their high-contrast settings through the Ease of Access Center, as shown here.
segment.target: Windows provides different high-contrast themes, and enables the user to set the specific colors to for their high-contrast settings through the Ease of Access Center, as shown here.

segment.source: Therefore, it's not possible to provide a definitive list of high-contrast color values.
segment.target: Therefore, it's not possible to provide a definitive list of high-contrast color values.

segment.source: The Windows high contrast settings UI
segment.target: The Windows high contrast settings UI

segment.source: For more info about supporting high-contrast themes, see High-contrast themes.
segment.target: For more info about supporting high-contrast themes, see High-contrast themes.

segment.source: In addition to the system high-contrast theme colors, the system accent color is provided as a special color resource using the key .
segment.target: In addition to the system high-contrast theme colors, the system accent color is provided as a special color resource using the key .

segment.source: At runtime, this resource gets the color that the user has specified as the accent color in the Windows personalization settings.
segment.target: At runtime, this resource gets the color that the user has specified as the accent color in the Windows personalization settings.

segment.source: NoteIt’s possible to override the system color resources for high-contrast color and accent color by creating resources with the same names, but it’s a best practice to respect the user’s color choices, especially for high-contrast settings.
segment.target: NoteIt’s possible to override the system color resources for high-contrast color and accent color by creating resources with the same names, but it’s a best practice to respect the user’s color choices, especially for high-contrast settings.

segment.source: The color resources shown in the preceding sections are used to set the Color property of SolidColorBrush resources in the system theme resource dictionaries.
segment.target: The color resources shown in the preceding sections are used to set the Color property of SolidColorBrush resources in the system theme resource dictionaries.

segment.source: You use the brush resources to apply the color to XAML elements.
segment.target: You use the brush resources to apply the color to XAML elements.

segment.source: The keys for the brush resources follow the naming format: .
segment.target: The keys for the brush resources follow the naming format: .

segment.source: Let’s look at how the color value for this brush is determined at run-time.
segment.target: Let’s look at how the color value for this brush is determined at run-time.

segment.source: In the "Light" and "Dark" resource dictionaries, this brush is defined like this:
segment.target: In the "Light" and "Dark" resource dictionaries, this brush is defined like this:

segment.source: In the "HighContrast" resource dictionary, this brush is defined like this:
segment.target: In the "HighContrast" resource dictionary, this brush is defined like this:

segment.source: When this brush is applied to a XAML element, its color is determined at run-time by the current theme, as shown in this table.
segment.target: When this brush is applied to a XAML element, its color is determined at run-time by the current theme, as shown in this table.

segment.source: The color specified in settings for the button background.
segment.target: The color specified in settings for the button background.

segment.source: You can use the naming scheme to determine which brush to apply to your own XAML elements.
segment.target: You can use the naming scheme to determine which brush to apply to your own XAML elements.

segment.source: NoteNot every combination of \[Simple HighContrast name\]\[Simple light/dark name\] is provided as a brush resource.
segment.target: NoteNot every combination of \[Simple HighContrast name\]\[Simple light/dark name\] is provided as a brush resource.

segment.source: The themeresources.xaml file defines several resources that define a Style that you can apply to text containers in your UI, specifically for either TextBlock or RichTextBlock.
segment.target: The themeresources.xaml file defines several resources that define a Style that you can apply to text containers in your UI, specifically for either TextBlock or RichTextBlock.

segment.source: These are not the default implicit styles.
segment.target: These are not the default implicit styles.

segment.source: They are provided to make it easier for you to create XAML UI definitions that match the Windows type ramp documented in Guidelines for fonts.
segment.target: They are provided to make it easier for you to create XAML UI definitions that match the Windows type ramp documented in Guidelines for fonts.

segment.source: These styles are for text attributes that you want applied to the whole text container.
segment.target: These styles are for text attributes that you want applied to the whole text container.

segment.source: If you want styles applied just to sections of the text, set attributes on the text elements within the container, such as on a Run in TextBlock.Inlines or on a Paragraph in RichTextBlock.Blocks.
segment.target: If you want styles applied just to sections of the text, set attributes on the text elements within the container, such as on a Run in TextBlock.Inlines or on a Paragraph in RichTextBlock.Blocks.

segment.source: The styles look like this when applied to a TextBlock:
segment.target: The styles look like this when applied to a TextBlock:

segment.source: Supplies the common properties for all the other TextBlock container styles.
segment.target: Supplies the common properties for all the other TextBlock container styles.

segment.source: Supplies the common properties for all the other RichTextBlock container styles.
segment.target: Supplies the common properties for all the other RichTextBlock container styles.

segment.source: Note The RichTextBlock styles don't have all the text ramp styles that TextBlock does, mainly because the block-based document object model for RichTextBlock makes it easier to set attributes on the individual text elements.
segment.target: Note The RichTextBlock styles don't have all the text ramp styles that TextBlock does, mainly because the block-based document object model for RichTextBlock makes it easier to set attributes on the individual text elements.

segment.source: Also, setting TextBlock.Text using the XAML content property introduces a situation where there is no text element to style and thus you'd have to style the container.
segment.target: Also, setting TextBlock.Text using the XAML content property introduces a situation where there is no text element to style and thus you'd have to style the container.

segment.source: That isn't an issue for RichTextBlock because its text content always has to be in specific text elements like Paragraph, which is where you might apply XAML styles for page header, page subheader and similar text ramp definitions.
segment.target: That isn't an issue for RichTextBlock because its text content always has to be in specific text elements like Paragraph, which is where you might apply XAML styles for page header, page subheader and similar text ramp definitions.

segment.source: There's an additional set of keyed Style definitions you can apply to style a Button differently than its default implicit style.
segment.target: There's an additional set of keyed Style definitions you can apply to style a Button differently than its default implicit style.

segment.source: Apply this style to a Button when you need to show text that a user can click to take action.
segment.target: Apply this style to a Button when you need to show text that a user can click to take action.

segment.source: The text is styled using the current accent color to distinguish it as interactive and has focus rectangles that work well for text.
segment.target: The text is styled using the current accent color to distinguish it as interactive and has focus rectangles that work well for text.

segment.source: Unlike the implicit style of a HyperlinkButton, the TextBlockButtonStyle does not underline the text.
segment.target: Unlike the implicit style of a HyperlinkButton, the TextBlockButtonStyle does not underline the text.

segment.source: The template also styles the presented text to use SystemControlHyperlinkBaseMediumBrush (for "PointerOver" state), SystemControlHighlightBaseMediumLowBrush (for "Pressed" state) and SystemControlDisabledBaseLowBrush (for "Disabled" state).
segment.target: The template also styles the presented text to use SystemControlHyperlinkBaseMediumBrush (for "PointerOver" state), SystemControlHighlightBaseMediumLowBrush (for "Pressed" state) and SystemControlDisabledBaseLowBrush (for "Disabled" state).

segment.source: Here's a Button with the TextBlockButtonStyle resource applied to it.
segment.target: Here's a Button with the TextBlockButtonStyle resource applied to it.

segment.source: A button styled to look like text
segment.target: A button styled to look like text

segment.source: This Style provides a complete template for a Button that can be the navigation back button for a navigation app.
segment.target: This Style provides a complete template for a Button that can be the navigation back button for a navigation app.

segment.source: It includes theme resource references that make this button use the Segoe MDL2 Assets symbol font, so you should use a Symbol value as the content rather than text.
segment.target: It includes theme resource references that make this button use the Segoe MDL2 Assets symbol font, so you should use a Symbol value as the content rather than text.

segment.source: The default dimensions are 40 x 40 pixels.
segment.target: The default dimensions are 40 x 40 pixels.

segment.source: To tailor the styling you can either explicitly set the Height, Width, FontSize, and other properties on your Button or create a derived style using BasedOn.
segment.target: To tailor the styling you can either explicitly set the Height, Width, FontSize, and other properties on your Button or create a derived style using BasedOn.

segment.source: Here's a Button with the NavigationBackButtonNormalStyle resource applied to it.
segment.target: Here's a Button with the NavigationBackButtonNormalStyle resource applied to it.

segment.source: A button styled as a back button
segment.target: A button styled as a back button

segment.source: This Style provides a complete template for a Button that can be the navigation back button for a navigation app.
segment.target: This Style provides a complete template for a Button that can be the navigation back button for a navigation app.

segment.source: It's similar to NavigationBackButtonNormalStyle, but its dimensions are 30 by 30 pixels.
segment.target: It's similar to NavigationBackButtonNormalStyle, but its dimensions are 30 by 30 pixels.

segment.source: Here's a Button with the NavigationBackButtonSmallStyle resource applied to it.
segment.target: Here's a Button with the NavigationBackButtonSmallStyle resource applied to it.

segment.source: If you don’t follow the guidelines for using theme resources, you might see unexpected behavior related to themes in your app.
segment.target: If you don’t follow the guidelines for using theme resources, you might see unexpected behavior related to themes in your app.

segment.source: For example, when you open a light-themed flyout, parts of your dark-themed app also change as if they were in the light theme.
segment.target: For example, when you open a light-themed flyout, parts of your dark-themed app also change as if they were in the light theme.

segment.source: Or if you navigate to a light-themed page and then navigate back, the original dark-themed page (or parts of it) now looks as though it is in the light theme.
segment.target: Or if you navigate to a light-themed page and then navigate back, the original dark-themed page (or parts of it) now looks as though it is in the light theme.

segment.source: Typically, these types of issues occur when you provide a "Default" theme and a "HighContrast" theme to support high-contrast scenarios, and then use both "Light" and "Dark" themes in different parts of your app.
segment.target: Typically, these types of issues occur when you provide a "Default" theme and a "HighContrast" theme to support high-contrast scenarios, and then use both "Light" and "Dark" themes in different parts of your app.

segment.source: For example, consider this theme dictionary definition:
segment.target: For example, consider this theme dictionary definition:

segment.source: You want to change the color pointed to by when in high-contrast, but when not in high-contrast, you rely on the {ThemeResource} markup extension to make sure that points to the right color for your theme.
segment.target: You want to change the color pointed to by when in high-contrast, but when not in high-contrast, you rely on the {ThemeResource} markup extension to make sure that points to the right color for your theme.

segment.source: If your app never has FrameworkElement.RequestedTheme set on elements within its visual tree, this will typically work as expected.
segment.target: If your app never has FrameworkElement.RequestedTheme set on elements within its visual tree, this will typically work as expected.

segment.source: However, you run into problems in your app as soon as you start to re-theme different parts of your visual tree.
segment.target: However, you run into problems in your app as soon as you start to re-theme different parts of your visual tree.

segment.source: The problem occurs because brushes are shared resources, unlike most other XAML types.
segment.target: The problem occurs because brushes are shared resources, unlike most other XAML types.

segment.source: If you have 2 elements in XAML sub-trees with different themes that reference the same brush resource, then as the framework walks each sub-tree to update its {ThemeResource} markup extension expressions, changes to the shared brush resource are reflected in the other sub-tree, which is not your intended result.
segment.target: If you have 2 elements in XAML sub-trees with different themes that reference the same brush resource, then as the framework walks each sub-tree to update its {ThemeResource} markup extension expressions, changes to the shared brush resource are reflected in the other sub-tree, which is not your intended result.

segment.source: To fix this, replace the "Default" dictionary with separate theme dictionaries for both "Light" and "Dark" themes in addition to "HighContrast":
segment.target: To fix this, replace the "Default" dictionary with separate theme dictionaries for both "Light" and "Dark" themes in addition to "HighContrast":

segment.source: However, problems still occur if any of these resources are referenced in inherited properties like Foreground.
segment.target: However, problems still occur if any of these resources are referenced in inherited properties like Foreground.

segment.source: Your custom control template might specify the foreground color of an element using the {ThemeResource} markup extension, but when the framework propagates the inherited value to child elements, it provides a direct reference to the resource that was resolved by the {ThemeResource} markup extension expression.
segment.target: Your custom control template might specify the foreground color of an element using the {ThemeResource} markup extension, but when the framework propagates the inherited value to child elements, it provides a direct reference to the resource that was resolved by the {ThemeResource} markup extension expression.

segment.source: This causes problems when the framework processes theme changes as it walks your control's visual tree.
segment.target: This causes problems when the framework processes theme changes as it walks your control's visual tree.

segment.source: It re-evaluates the {ThemeResource} markup extension expression to get a new brush resource but doesn’t yet propagate this reference down to the children of your control; this happens later, such as during the next measure pass.
segment.target: It re-evaluates the {ThemeResource} markup extension expression to get a new brush resource but doesn’t yet propagate this reference down to the children of your control; this happens later, such as during the next measure pass.

segment.source: As a result, after walking the control visual tree in response to a theme change, the framework walks the children and updates any {ThemeResource} markup extension expressions set on them, or on objects set on their properties.
segment.target: As a result, after walking the control visual tree in response to a theme change, the framework walks the children and updates any {ThemeResource} markup extension expressions set on them, or on objects set on their properties.

segment.source: This is where the problem occurs; the framework walks the brush resource and because it specifies its color using a {ThemeResource} markup extension, it's re-evaluated.
segment.target: This is where the problem occurs; the framework walks the brush resource and because it specifies its color using a {ThemeResource} markup extension, it's re-evaluated.

segment.source: At this point, the framework appears to have polluted your theme dictionary because it now has a resource from one dictionary that has its color set from another dictionary.
segment.target: At this point, the framework appears to have polluted your theme dictionary because it now has a resource from one dictionary that has its color set from another dictionary.

segment.source: To fix this problem, use the {StaticResource} markup extension instead of {ThemeResource} markup extension.
segment.target: To fix this problem, use the {StaticResource} markup extension instead of {ThemeResource} markup extension.

segment.source: With the guidelines applied, the theme dictionaries look like this:
segment.target: With the guidelines applied, the theme dictionaries look like this:

segment.source: Notice that the {ThemeResource} markup extension is still used in the "HighContrast" dictionary instead of {StaticResource} markup extension.
segment.target: Notice that the {ThemeResource} markup extension is still used in the "HighContrast" dictionary instead of {StaticResource} markup extension.

segment.source: This situation falls under the exception given earlier in the guidelines.
segment.target: This situation falls under the exception given earlier in the guidelines.

segment.source: Most of the brush values that are used for the "HighContrast" theme are using color choices that are globally controlled by the system, but exposed to XAML as a specially-named resource (those prefixed with ‘SystemColor’ in the name).
segment.target: Most of the brush values that are used for the "HighContrast" theme are using color choices that are globally controlled by the system, but exposed to XAML as a specially-named resource (those prefixed with ‘SystemColor’ in the name).

segment.source: The system enables the user to set the specific colors that should be used for their high contrast settings through the Ease of Access Center.
segment.target: The system enables the user to set the specific colors that should be used for their high contrast settings through the Ease of Access Center.

segment.source: Those color choices are applied to the specially-named resources.
segment.target: Those color choices are applied to the specially-named resources.

segment.source: The XAML framework uses the same theme changed event to also update these brushes when it detects they’ve changed at the system level.
segment.target: The XAML framework uses the same theme changed event to also update these brushes when it detects they’ve changed at the system level.

segment.source: This is why the {ThemeResource} markup extension is used here.
segment.target: This is why the {ThemeResource} markup extension is used here.

segment.source: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
segment.target: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
